tn.text: Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Jerusalem in exile through Isaiah.
Yahweh speaks of blessing the people freely as if he were selling food and drink to needy people for free. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The repetition of this word four times adds a sense of urgency to the invitation.

tn.ref: buy wine and milk without money and without cost
tn.text: There is a sense of irony in this statement since a person usually has to use money to buy something. This emphasizes Yahweh's amazing grace in giving these things freely. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Jerusalem.

tn.ref: Why do you weigh out silver for what is not bread?
tn.text: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke the people. He speaks of the people seeking happiness apart from Yahweh as if they were purchasing things to eat that were not food. AT: "You should not weigh out silver for what is not bread." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to counting silver coins in order to pay someone for something. AT: "pay money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here the word "bread" represents food in general. It is implied that the people were buying things to eat that were not really food. AT: "for things to eat that are not really food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: why do you labor for what does not satisfy?
tn.text: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke the people. He speaks of them seeking happiness apart from Yahweh as if they were working to earn money to buy things that could not satisfy them. AT: "you should not be working for money to spend on things that do not satisfy." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: eat what is good, and delight yourselves in fatness
tn.text: The people trusting Yahweh for blessing and happiness is spoken of as if they are eating good food that is making them happy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "fatness" refers to meat that has plenty of fat on it and is an idiom for fine food. AT: "with the best foods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Listening to or paying attention to someone is spoken of as if it were turning one's ears to someone. AT: "Pay attention" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "faithful love that I promised to David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Possible meanings are 1) this refers to what Yahweh did for King David in the past or 2) it refers to what God will do through one of David's descendants.
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Jerusalem.
Translate this phrase in the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:01:04|1:4]].

tn.ref: Seek Yahweh while he may be found
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Seek Yahweh while you can still find him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Let the wicked leave his path
tn.text: The word "wicked" refers to wicked people. Yahweh speaks of wicked people no longer sinning as if they were to stop walking along a path that they had been traveling. AT: "Let wicked people change the way they live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: and the man of sin his thoughts
tn.text: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. AT: "and let the sinful man leave his thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Possible meanings are 1) "the way he thinks" or 2) "his plans"
"and Yahweh will pity him"
The verb may be supplied from the first phrase in this sentence. AT: "and let him return to our God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Jerusalem.

This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "declaration" is expressed as the verb "declared" or "solemnly said." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:14:21|14:22]]. AT: "this is what Yahweh has declared" or "this is what Yahweh has solemnly said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: for as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways, and my thoughts than your thoughts
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of the things that he does and how he thinks as being far superior to or higher than what people do and think, just like the sky is much higher than the earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Jerusalem.

tn.ref: For as the rain and snow ... do not return there
tn.text: This is likely a description of the rain and snow evaporating.

tn.ref: so also my word ... it will succeed in that for which I sent it
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of his word as if it were a person whom he sends out as his messenger to accomplish a task. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: my word will be that goes from my mouth
tn.text: Here the word "mouth" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "the word that I speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: it will not return to me useless
tn.text: Here the description of the word returning to Yahweh means that it has completed the task that Yahweh had sent it to complete. That it will not return "useless" means that it will not fail to accomplish its task. AT: "it will not fail to complete its task" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: but it will accomplish that which I wish, and it will succeed in that for which I sent it
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that what Yahweh says will always happen. AT: "but I will accomplish what I wish, and the things that I speak I will cause to happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Jerusalem.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will lead you along peacefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the mountains and the hills will break out in joyful shouts before you, and all the trees of the fields will clap their hands
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of the mountains, hills, and trees as if they were people with voices and hands, celebrating as Yahweh rescues his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Instead of the thornbushes, the cypress will grow; and instead of the brier, the myrtle tree will grow
tn.text: The words "thornbushes" and "brier" refer to species of plants that have sharp thorns growing on them. The words "cypress" and "myrtle" refer to species of evergreen trees. The thorny plants symbolize desolation, while the evergreens symbolize life and prosperity. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Here the word "name" represents Yahweh's fame. AT: "for his fame" or "for his honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: that will not be cut off
tn.text: Something ceasing to exist is spoken of as if it were cut off, as a branch is cut off of a tree or a piece of fabric is cut off of clothing. This can be stated in active form. AT: "that will never end" or "that will last forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
